author: Zairieminx
body:
I'd wager to also be careful because during these times some stocks that are red can be green by end of year or later. I'd much rather a stock go zero before I give up now more than ever. It might not mean much, but I learned 2 very important lessons with ENPH and AMD (use to be $1 I was in got out FAR TOO SOON). 

Then again I'm also in ETF's as well, and now I plan to put my attention far more into those than just individual stocks.

author: jtrub42
body:
The question shouldn’t be “is it overvalued?” At this P/E ratio (currently sitting at ~278) it is definitely overvalued. The question is whether or not you should buy an overvalued stock. In this case, my opinion is yes. It’s been overvalued for so long because institutional investors anticipate the company’s value will eventually catch up to and exceed its current valuation. I like $ENPH as a long-term hold. I don’t have the omnipotence to predict dips or rallies so I add to my position regularly. It’s a strong company with a good product and positive trajectory. 

Conflict of Interest: I hold 110 shares at ~$151 average cost.

Obviously they produce semiconductors, but I would make the argument for energy simply because of which ETFs hold ENPH as a large part of its portfolio. In descending order of exposure, there is:


>8.25% of TAN (Invesco Solar ETF)

>7.86% of FXN (First Trust Energy AlphaDEX Fund)

>5.87% of ICLN (iShared Global Clean Energy ETF)


and the list goes on, all of which are energy related.

author: Ensemble_InABox
body:
Green energy is my pick. ENPH, SEDG are the two most likely to continue growing. ENPH has far better margins and a better roadmap, but there's space for solar edge as well.

RUN, and SPWR are IMO the best panel plays, but I stick to inverters (ENPH). It's worked out very well for me over the past 3 years, and despite the major loss of confidence from Feb until now, I don't feel too worried about having a major chunk of my portfolio in it.

author: IndependentDatabase1
body:
TSLA already sells solar roofing and power walls. I think they have strong competition there from ENPH and maybe others. Self-driving cars are unfortunately not as easy to release, but even their release is already priced in in the stock price. Charge stations - competition from PLUG and others. Overall, TSLA is a great company, but the stock prices in a very optimistic scenario, so I doubt it's a great investment currently.

So cars manufacturer can have a tech valuation, but a company selling hardware and software (elgato streaming software) and running online platform (gaming coaching) will never get a tech valuation? I dunno. I would disagree.

Anyway, even if CRSR maintains P/E of 17, the stock can easily 2-4x in the next 2-5 years. CRSR is spending a lot now on R&D and marketing: they launch multiple new products every month and they are advertised everywhere - they're everywhere on TikTok, which is where kids spend time nowadays. Also, they're paying off their high-interest debt. Once they cut R&D and marketing spending and trim debt, their earnings will be massively larger than currently.

author: raniumPU-36
body:
I bought ENPH (Enphase Energy) at just over $14 right about the time trump started his tariff war with China Mayish of 19. I’ve leveraged up a bit since, but it was over $200 by the time the covid crash rebounded. Every time I think it’s maxed out it just goes up again. Very volatile  too if you’re a swinger. NTRA is another one. Excellent growth but with good swing volatility. My second biggest all time grosser next to Tesla. 
Disclaimer I am an idiot this is not advice. No one in their right mind would listen to me. (But check them out 😉)

author: Edibleglass69420
body:
I’ve taken control of my retirement fund there are ver limited options available.  One is American funds euro pacific growth fund f5.  Is it worth keeping money in this just for the sake of diversification?  It’s done ok last year but severely underperformed overall.  

I’m thinking about just throwing all of it in vanguard institutional funds (voo) basically and vanguard mid cap (vo). The American funds has a much higher fee much lower return historically and a much lower dividend yield as well.  Is there any reason to think this fund will outperform in the future to justify the extra expenses?
